column2: CHAPTER 3
column3: CHAPTER three

column2: TORNADOES
column3: TORNADOES

column2: * _When a tornado watch (forecast) is announced_, this means that tornadoes are expected in or near your area.
column3: asterisk underscore When a tornado watch (forecast) is announced underscore, this means that tornadoes are expected in or near your area.

column2: Keep your radio or television set tuned to a local station for information and advice from your local government or the Weather Bureau.
column3: Keep your radio or television set tuned to a local station for information and advice from your local government or the Weather Bureau.

column2: Also, keep watching the sky, especially to the south and southwest.
column3: Also, keep watching the sky, especially to the south and southwest.

column2: (When a tornado watch is announced during the approach of a hurricane, however, keep watching the sky to the east.) If you see any revolving, funnel-shaped clouds, report them by telephone immediately to your local police department, sheriff's office or Weather Bureau office.
column3: (When a tornado watch is announced during the approach of a hurricane, however, keep watching the sky to the east.) If you see any revolving, funnel shaped clouds, report them by telephone immediately to your local police department, sheriff's office or Weather Bureau office.

column2: But do not use the phone to get information and advice--depend on radio or TV.
column3: But do not use the phone to get information and advice-depend on radio or t v.

column2: * _When a tornado warning is issued, take shelter immediately_.
column3: asterisk underscore When a tornado warning is issued, take shelter immediately underscore.

column2: The warning means that a tornado has actually been sighted, and this (or other tornadoes) may strike in your vicinity.
column3: The warning means that a tornado has actually been sighted, and this (or other tornadoes) may strike in your vicinity.

column2: You must take action to protect yourself from being blown away, struck by falling objects, or injured by flying debris.
column3: You must take action to protect yourself from being blown away, struck by falling objects, or injured by flying debris.

column2: Your best protection is an underground shelter or cave, or a substantial steel-framed or reinforced-concrete building. But if none of these is available, there are other places where you can take refuge:
column3: Your best protection is an underground shelter or cave, or a substantial steel framed or reinforced concrete building. But if none of these is available, there are other places where you can take refuge:

column2: --If you are _at home_, go to your underground storm cellar or your basement fallout shelter, if you have one.
column3: --If you are underscore at home underscore, go to your underground storm cellar or your basement fallout shelter, if you have one.

column2: If not, go to a corner of your home basement and take cover under a sturdy workbench or table (but not underneath heavy appliances on the floor above).
column3: If not, go to a corner of your home basement and take cover under a sturdy workbench or table (but not underneath heavy appliances on the floor above).

column2: If your home has no basement, take cover under heavy furniture on the ground floor in the center part of the house, or in a small room on the ground floor that is away from outside walls and windows.
column3: If your home has no basement, take cover under heavy furniture on the ground floor in the center part of the house, or in a small room on the ground floor that is away from outside walls and windows.

column2: (As a last resort, go outside to a nearby ditch, excavation, culvert or ravine.) Doors and windows on the sides of your house _away from_, the tornado may be left open to help reduce damage to the building, but stay away from them to avoid flying debris.
column3: (As a last resort, go outside to a nearby ditch, excavation, culvert or ravine.) Doors and windows on the sides of your house underscore away from underscore, the tornado may be left open to help reduce damage to the building, but stay away from them to avoid flying debris.

column2: Do not remain in a trailer or mobile home if a tornado is approaching; take cover elsewhere.
column3: Do not remain in a trailer or mobile home if a tornado is approaching; take cover elsewhere.

column2: --If you are _at work_ in an office building, go to the basement or to an inner hallway on a lower floor.
column3: --If you are underscore at work underscore in an office building, go to the basement or to an inner hallway on a lower floor.

column2: In a factory, go to a shelter area, or to the basement if there is one.
column3: In a factory, go to a shelter area, or to the basement if there is one.

column2: --If you are _outside in open country_, drive away from the tornado's path, at a right angle to it.
column3: --If you are underscore outside in open country underscore, drive away from the tornado's path, at a right angle to it.

column2: If there isn't time to do this--or if you are walking--take cover and lie flat in the nearest depression, such as a ditch, culvert, excavation, or ravine.
column3: If there isn't time to do this-or if you are walking-take cover and lie flat in the nearest depression, such as a ditch, culvert, excavation, or ravine.

column2: CHAPTER 4
column3: CHAPTER four

column2: WINTER STORMS
column3: WINTER STORMS

column2: Here is advice that will help you protect yourself and your family against the hazards of winter storms--blizzards, heavy snows, ice storms, freezing rain, or sleet.
column3: Here is advice that will help you protect yourself and your family against the hazards of winter storms-blizzards, heavy snows, ice storms, freezing rain, or sleet.

column2: * KEEP POSTED ON WEATHER CONDITIONS.
column3: asterisk KEEP POSTED ON WEATHER CONDITIONS.

column2: Use your radio, television and newspapers to keep informed of current weather conditions and forecasts in your area.
column3: Use your radio, television and newspapers to keep informed of current weather conditions and forecasts in your area.

column2: Even a few hours' warning of a storm may enable you to avoid being caught outside in it, or at least be better prepared to cope with it.
column3: Even a few hours' warning of a storm may enable you to avoid being caught outside in it, or at least be better prepared to cope with it.

column2: You should also understand the terms commonly used in weather forecasts:
column3: You should also understand the terms commonly used in weather forecasts:

column2: --A _blizzard_ is the most dangerous of all winter storms.
column3: --A underscore blizzard underscore is the most dangerous of all winter storms.

column2: It combines cold air, heavy snow, and strong winds that blow the snow about and may reduce visibility to only a few yards.
column3: It combines cold air, heavy snow, and strong winds that blow the snow about and may reduce visibility to only a few yards.

column2: A _blizzard warning_ is issued when the Weather Bureau expects considerable snow, winds of 35 miles an hour or more, and temperatures of 20 degrees Fahrenheit or lower.
column3: A underscore blizzard warning underscore is issued when the Weather Bureau expects considerable snow, winds of thirty five miles an hour or more, and temperatures of twenty degrees Fahrenheit or lower.

column2: A _severe blizzard warning_ means that a very heavy snowfall is expected, with winds of at least 45 miles an hour and temperatures of 10 degrees or lower.
column3: A underscore severe blizzard warning underscore means that a very heavy snowfall is expected, with winds of at least forty five miles an hour and temperatures of ten degrees or lower.

column2: --A _heavy snow warning_ usually means an expected snowfall of 4 inches or more in a 12-hour period, or 6 inches or more in a 24-hour period. Warnings of _snow flurries, snow squalls_, or _blowing and drifting snow_ are important mainly because visibility may be reduced and roads may become slippery or blocked.
column3: --A underscore heavy snow warning underscore usually means an expected snowfall of four inches or more in a twelve-hour period, or six inches or more in a twenty four-hour period. Warnings of underscore snow flurries, snow squalls underscore, or underscore blowing and drifting snow underscore are important mainly because visibility may be reduced and roads may become slippery or blocked.

column2: --_Freezing rain or freezing drizzle_ is forecast when expected rain is likely to freeze as soon as it strikes the ground, putting a coating of ice or glaze on roads and everything else that is exposed.
column3: --underscore Freezing rain or freezing drizzle underscore is forecast when expected rain is likely to freeze as soon as it strikes the ground, putting a coating of ice or glaze on roads and everything else that is exposed.

column2: If a substantial layer of ice is expected to accumulate from the freezing rain, an _ice storm_ is forecast.
column3: If a substantial layer of ice is expected to accumulate from the freezing rain, an underscore ice storm underscore is forecast.

column2: --_Sleet_ is small particles of ice, usually mixed with rain.
column3: --underscore Sleet underscore is small particles of ice, usually mixed with rain.

column2: If enough sleet accumulates on the ground, it will make the roads slippery.
column3: If enough sleet accumulates on the ground, it will make the roads slippery.

column2: * BE PREPARED FOR ISOLATION AT HOME.
column3: asterisk BE PREPARED FOR ISOLATION AT HOME.

column2: If you live in a rural area, make sure you could survive at home for a week or two in case a storm isolated you and made it impossible for you to leave.
column3: If you live in a rural area, make sure you could survive at home for a week or two in case a storm isolated you and made it impossible for you to leave.

column2: You should:
column3: You should:

column2: --Keep an adequate supply of heating fuel on hand and use it sparingly, as your regular supplies may be curtailed by storm conditions.
column3: --Keep an adequate supply of heating fuel on hand and use it sparingly, as your regular supplies may be curtailed by storm conditions.

column2: If necessary, conserve fuel by keeping the house cooler than usual, or by "closing off" some rooms temporarily.
column3: If necessary, conserve fuel by keeping the house cooler than usual, or by "closing off" some rooms temporarily.

column2: Also, have available some kind of _emergency_ heating equipment and fuel so you could keep at least one room of your house warm enough to be livable.
column3: Also, have available some kind of underscore emergency underscore heating equipment and fuel so you could keep at least one room of your house warm enough to be livable.

column2: This could be a camp stove with fuel, or a supply of wood or coal if you have a fireplace.
column3: This could be a camp stove with fuel, or a supply of wood or coal if you have a fireplace.

column2: If your furnace is controlled by a thermostat and your electricity is cut off by a storm, the furnace probably would not operate and you would need emergency heat.
column3: If your furnace is controlled by a thermostat and your electricity is cut off by a storm, the furnace probably would not operate and you would need emergency heat.

column2: --Stock an emergency supply of food and water, as well as emergency cooking equipment such as a camp stove.
column3: --Stock an emergency supply of food and water, as well as emergency cooking equipment such as a camp stove.

column2: Some of this food should be of the type that does not require refrigeration or cooking.
column3: Some of this food should be of the type that does not require refrigeration or cooking.

column2: --Make sure you have a battery-powered radio and extra batteries on hand, so that if your electric power is cut off you could still hear weather forecasts, information and advice broadcast by local authorities.
column3: --Make sure you have a battery powered radio and extra batteries on hand, so that if your electric power is cut off you could still hear weather forecasts, information and advice broadcast by local authorities.

column2: Also, flashlights or lanterns would be needed.
column3: Also, flashlights or lanterns would be needed.

column2: --Consult page 72 of this handbook for other supplies and equipment that you may need if isolated at home.
column3: --Consult page seventy two of this handbook for other supplies and equipment that you may need if isolated at home.

column2: Be sure to keep on hand the simple tools and equipment needed to fight a fire.
column3: Be sure to keep on hand the simple tools and equipment needed to fight a fire.

column2: Also, be certain that all family members know how to take precautions that would prevent fire at such a time, when the help of the fire department may not be available.
column3: Also, be certain that all family members know how to take precautions that would prevent fire at such a time, when the help of the fire department may not be available.

column2: * TRAVEL ONLY IF NECESSARY.
column3: asterisk TRAVEL ONLY IF NECESSARY.

column2: Avoid all unnecessary trips.
column3: Avoid all unnecessary trips.

column2: If you must travel, use public transportation if possible.
column3: If you must travel, use public transportation if possible.

column2: However, if you are forced to use your automobile for a trip of any distance, take these precautions:
column3: However, if you are forced to use your automobile for a trip of any distance, take these precautions:

column2: --Make sure your car is in good operating condition, properly serviced, and equipped with chains or snow tires.
column3: --Make sure your car is in good operating condition, properly serviced, and equipped with chains or snow tires.

column2: --Take another person with you if possible.
column3: --Take another person with you if possible.

column2: --Make sure someone knows where you are going, your approximate schedule, and your estimated time of arrival at your destination.
column3: --Make sure someone knows where you are going, your approximate schedule, and your estimated time of arrival at your destination.

column2: --Have emergency "winter storm supplies" in the car, such as a container of sand, shovel, windshield scraper, tow chain or rope, extra gasoline, and a flashlight.
column3: --Have emergency "winter storm supplies" in the car, such as a container of sand, shovel, windshield scraper, tow chain or rope, extra gasoline, and a flashlight.

column2: It also is good to have with you heavy gloves or mittens, overshoes, extra woolen socks, and winter headgear to cover your head and face.
column3: It also is good to have with you heavy gloves or mittens, overshoes, extra woolen socks, and winter headgear to cover your head and face.

column2: --Travel by daylight and use major highways if you can.
column3: --Travel by daylight and use major highways if you can.

column2: Keep the car radio turned on for weather information and advice.
column3: Keep the car radio turned on for weather information and advice.

column2: --Drive with all possible caution.
column3: --Drive with all possible caution.

column2: Don't try to save time by travelling faster than road and weather conditions permit.
column3: Don't try to save time by travelling faster than road and weather conditions permit.

column2: --Don't be daring or foolhardy.
column3: --Don't be daring or foolhardy.

column2: Stop, turn back, or seek help if conditions threaten that may test your ability or endurance, rather than risk being stalled, lost or isolated.
column3: Stop, turn back, or seek help if conditions threaten that may test your ability or endurance, rather than risk being stalled, lost or isolated.

column2: If you are caught in a _blizzard_, seek refuge immediately.
column3: If you are caught in a underscore blizzard underscore, seek refuge immediately.

column2: * KEEP CALM IF YOU GET IN TROUBLE.
column3: asterisk KEEP CALM IF YOU GET IN TROUBLE.

column2: If your car breaks down during a storm, or if you become stalled or lost, don't panic.
column3: If your car breaks down during a storm, or if you become stalled or lost, don't panic.

column2: Think the problem through, decide what's the safest and best thing to do, and then do it slowly and carefully.
column3: Think the problem through, decide what's the safest and best thing to do, and then do it slowly and carefully.

column2: If you are on a well-traveled road, show a trouble signal.
column3: If you are on a well traveled road, show a trouble signal.

column2: Set your directional lights to flashing, raise the hood of your car, or hang a cloth from the radio aerial or car window.
column3: Set your directional lights to flashing, raise the hood of your car, or hang a cloth from the radio aerial or car window.

column2: Then stay in your car and wait for help to arrive.
column3: Then stay in your car and wait for help to arrive.

column2: If you run the engine to keep warm, remember to open a window enough to provide ventilation and protect you from carbon monoxide poisoning.
column3: If you run the engine to keep warm, remember to open a window enough to provide ventilation and protect you from carbon monoxide poisoning.

column2: Wherever you are, if there is no house or other source of help in sight, do not leave your car to search for assistance, as you may become confused and get lost.
column3: Wherever you are, if there is no house or other source of help in sight, do not leave your car to search for assistance, as you may become confused and get lost.

column2: * AVOID OVEREXERTION.
column3: asterisk AVOID OVEREXERTION.

column2: Every winter many unnecessary deaths occur because people--especially older persons, but younger ones as well--engage in more strenuous physical activity than their bodies can stand.
column3: Every winter many unnecessary deaths occur because people-especially older persons, but younger ones as well-engage in more strenuous physical activity than their bodies can stand.

column2: Cold weather itself, _without_ any physical exertion, puts an extra strain on your heart.
column3: Cold weather itself, underscore without underscore any physical exertion, puts an extra strain on your heart.

column2: If you add to this physical exercise, especially exercise that you are not accustomed to--such as shovelling snow, pushing an automobile, or even walking fast or far--you are risking a heart attack, a stroke, or other damage to your body.
column3: If you add to this physical exercise, especially exercise that you are not accustomed to-such as shovelling snow, pushing an automobile, or even walking fast or far-you are risking a heart attack, a stroke, or other damage to your body.

column2: In winter weather, and especially in winter storms, be aware of this danger, and avoid overexertion.
column3: In winter weather, and especially in winter storms, be aware of this danger, and avoid overexertion.

column2: CHAPTER 5
column3: CHAPTER five

column2: EARTHQUAKES
column3: EARTHQUAKES

column2: If your area is one of the places in the United States where earthquakes occur, keep these points in mind:
column3: If your area is one of the places in the United States where earthquakes occur, keep these points in mind:

column2: --When an earthquake happens, _keep calm_.
column3: --When an earthquake happens, underscore keep calm underscore.

column2: Don't run or panic.
column3: Don't run or panic.

column2: If you take the proper precautions, the chances are you will not be hurt.
column3: If you take the proper precautions, the chances are you will not be hurt.

column2: --REMAIN WHERE YOU ARE.
column3: --REMAIN WHERE YOU ARE.

column2: If you are outdoors, stay outdoors; if indoors, stay indoors.
column3: If you are outdoors, stay outdoors; if indoors, stay indoors.

column2: In earthquakes, most injuries occur as people are entering or leaving buildings (from falling walls, electric wires, etc.).
column3: In earthquakes, most injuries occur as people are entering or leaving buildings (from falling walls, electric wires, etc).

column2: --If you are indoors, sit or stand against an inside wall (preferably in the basement), or in an inside doorway; or else take cover under a desk, table or bench (in case the wall or ceiling should fall).
column3: --If you are indoors, sit or stand against an inside wall (preferably in the basement), or in an inside doorway; or else take cover under a desk, table or bench (in case the wall or ceiling should fall).

column2: Stay away from windows and outside doors.
column3: Stay away from windows and outside doors.

column2: --If you are outdoors, stay away from overhead electric wires, poles or anything else that might shake loose and fall (such as the cornices of tall buildings).
column3: --If you are outdoors, stay away from overhead electric wires, poles or anything else that might shake loose and fall (such as the cornices of tall buildings).

column2: --If you are _driving an automobile_, pull off the road and stop (as soon as possible, and with caution).
column3: --If you are underscore driving an automobile underscore, pull off the road and stop (as soon as possible, and with caution).

column2: Remain in the car until the disturbance subsides.
column3: Remain in the car until the disturbance subsides.

column2: When you drive on, watch for hazards created by the earthquake, such as fallen or falling objects, downed electric wires, and broken or undermined roadways.
column3: When you drive on, watch for hazards created by the earthquake, such as fallen or falling objects, downed electric wires, and broken or undermined roadways.

column2: AFTER AN EARTHQUAKE
column3: AFTER AN EARTHQUAKE

column2: For your own safety and that of others, you should follow carefully the advice given in the section, "After a Natural Disaster" (page 73).
column3: For your own safety and that of others, you should follow carefully the advice given in the section, "After a Natural Disaster" (page seventy three).

column3: INDEX

column3: Air raid underscore see underscore NUCLEAR ATTACK
